publicationStmt.publisher: ENGL668 Critical Topics in Digital Studies Course

msIdentifier.repository: University of Maryland University Libraries, College Park MD

interpGrp.desc: Silences and abscences of women of color students at Maryland

editorialDecl.p: Structural formatting has been mostly preserved, including paragraphs and column breaks, and line breaks indicated when interrupting words.

projectDesc.p: This brief project aims to trace the inclusivity of the University of Maryland's cheerleading squad through the lens of the Diamondback's coverage of the squad's discrimination in the 1960s and 1970s.

personGrp.note: This person group is necessary to point to the specific discrimination faced by women of color in social, athletic, academic, and institutional contexts.
This person group is necessary to racialize the otherwise neutral language used by the student journalists operating under the assumption that whiteness is the neutral default.
This person group is necessary to point to the positionality of black and African American people beyond potentially simplifying and monolithic language.

div.p:
Student Government Association Legislature voted last night to conduct an Investigation into the present cheerleader selection process be­
causebecause of alleged racial discrimina­
tiondiscrimination.

Legislator Cheryl Williams, who proposed the Investigation, charged the 12-member cheerleader selection panel practiced a “blatent form of institutional racism” because it did not select any of the seven blacks who tried out for the seven vacant posi­
tionspositions on the 10-girl squad.
According to Williams, two of the seven blacks made it to the top ten but were not among the girls chosen to fill out the squad. The squad will have no black members next year.
Last December Angie Sharp and Jacqueline Robinson became the first black cheerleaders on the squad in 30 years. Robinson dropped off the squad last year; Sharp will leave in June.

In addition, legislature is now draw­
ingdrawing up a proposal concerning the stu­
dentstudent activity fee to present to Chancel­lor Charles E. Bishop’s committee which Isis studying the question of how the fee should be collected and dis­
tributeddistributed.
The proposal under consideration will recommend that the fee remain mandatory but that it be placed in a revolving account for SGA use ex­clusively.
The group also expressed concern for student library help.
Legislator Pat Leer will head a committee which will meet with Bishop to discuss obtaining funds for staffing the library with more students to work in the stacks.

Leer, who is a library employee, said the number of student workers has been cut because of a recent library budget cut by the Univer­
sityUniversity. He claims the reduced amount of help will cause books to be shelved more slowly and make it impossible for students to locate books they need for course work.

The legislature also endorsed a move by John Daly that the Student Union Board join an association of Student Union Boards of colleges and universities in the greater Washing­
tonWashington area. The association, which will include American, Catholic, George Washington and Georgetown Univer­
sitiesUniversities and George Mason College as well as the University, is being cre­
atedcreated to establish greater coopera­
tioncooperation in the exchange of informationon student planned events.
